nodes.author: Gershenfeld, N.
nodes.title: Fab: The Coming Revolution on Your Desktop — from Personal Computers to Personal Fabrication
nodes.Description:
Neil Gershenfeld’s Fab: The Coming Revolution on Your Desktop (2008) argues that digital fabrication represents a decisive break from the industrial division between conception and execution. Building on the ethos of “personal computing,” Gershenfeld proposes “personal fabrication”: the idea that individuals should be able to design and produce physical objects with the same freedom and accessibility that computers brought to information. At the center of this vision are Fab Labs—small, distributed workshops equipped with laser cutters, CNC machines, microcontrollers, and 3D printers—designed not merely as technical spaces but as pedagogical and civic infrastructures. In Fab Labs, people learn how things work by making them, collapsing the epistemic gulf that Simone Weil diagnosed as the root of modern alienation.

For Gershenfeld, digital fabrication does not automate creativity; it restores agency by reuniting thinking and making. Code becomes material instruction, and fabrication becomes a site of reciprocity rather than hierarchy. Fab Labs demonstrate that when methods are shared rather than hidden, communities appropriate technologies to address local needs, weaving global knowledge into situated practices. This decentralization challenges the industrial logic of scale: production no longer requires centralized factories, because customization and variation cost no more than repetition.

Yet Gershenfeld’s revolution is ultimately educational and political. Democratizing fabrication means democratizing intelligibility—giving people the capacity to understand and modify the systems that shape their lives. In this sense, Fab anticipates the contemporary post-digital challenge: ensuring that distributed technological power remains legible, accessible, and participatory rather than reabsorbed into opaque computational infrastructures.

nodes.author: Baudisch, P.; Mueller, S.
nodes.title: Personal Fabrication
nodes.publisher: Foundations and Trends® in Human–Computer Interaction [Internet];10(3–4):165–293
nodes.Description:
Baudisch and Mueller’s Personal Fabrication (2016) outlines the evolution of fabrication technologies from industrially controlled systems toward increasingly democratized, consumer-accessible tools. The authors frame this transition through an AD/DA (Analog-to-Digital/Digital-to-Analog) paradigm, positioning fabrication within the same lineage as earlier digital revolutions in publishing, music, and video. As patents expired and hardware costs fell, fabrication shifted from closed industrial ecosystems to open, maker-led environments characterized by low-cost, hackable, and networked machines. This process, they argue, will culminate in the widespread adoption of “personal fabrication,” where users can design and produce their own physical objects through interactive digital systems. The authors identify six interdependent challenges that must be addressed for this transition to mature: (1) hardware and materials accessibility, (2) embedded domain knowledge, (3) interactive feedback, (4) machine-specific abstraction, (5) sustainability, and (6) intellectual property management.

In relation to the dissertation Post-Anthropogenic Design-to-Fabrication Practices Towards Global Symbiosis, Baudisch and Mueller’s framework provides an essential theoretical and technological foundation. Their notion of decentralized, open, and embodied fabrication directly aligns with the dissertation’s concept of open design ecologies and transcalar fabrication, where making is distributed across networks of human and non-human agents. The “personal” dimension they describe becomes, in a post-anthropogenic reading, post-personal—a condition in which design intelligence is shared among computational, biological, and material systems. Similarly, their emphasis on sustainability anticipates the dissertation’s argument for global symbiosis, where fabrication operates within ecological reciprocity rather than extractive industrial logics. By embedding expertise and feedback within software-hardware assemblages, Baudisch and Mueller’s vision gestures toward self-organizing, adaptive fabrication ecologies that move beyond human-centered production. Thus, their analysis represents not only a technological precedent but also a transitional paradigm toward the non-standard, symbiotic, and decentralized design-to-fabrication practices that define post-anthropogenic tectonics.

nodes.author: Diamond, J. M.
nodes.title: Guns, Germs, and Steel: The Fates of Human Societies
nodes.Description:
Jared Diamond’s Guns, Germs, and Steel: The Fates of Human Societies (1997) offers a material and ecological explanation for the unequal development of human civilizations. Diamond argues that disparities in access to resources—particularly domesticable plants and animals, geographic orientation, and environmental stability—determined which societies could accumulate surpluses, specialize labor, and develop complex technologies. Civilizational progress, in this view, is not rooted in cultural superiority but in unequal access to enabling ecologies and the ability to exchange and replicate knowledge, materials, and techniques across regions. Diamond highlights how the diffusion of agriculture, metallurgy, and writing relied on copying and adaptation, where ideas and technologies were reinterpreted within new local contexts, creating an iterative network of innovation.

This framework resonates deeply with the dissertation Post-Anthropogenic Design-to-Fabrication Practices Towards Global Symbiosis, which reimagines design and fabrication as decentralized, open, and symbiotic systems rather than hierarchically controlled industrial processes. Diamond’s historical analysis of inequality underscores the danger of resource concentration—a pattern mirrored today in the global distribution of fabrication infrastructure, computational power, and material access. Just as early civilizations flourished through the free flow of resources and knowledge, a post-anthropogenic paradigm seeks to dissolve these asymmetries by promoting open-source fabrication networks and transcalar material exchange among human and non-human agents.

In this context, copying becomes an ethical and generative act—a means of ecological and cultural resilience rather than mere replication. The dissertation extends Diamond’s logic into a speculative future: where fabrication is no longer constrained by geopolitical or anthropocentric borders but operates as a distributed ecology of making, driven by reciprocal access, shared intelligence, and material symbiosis. Thus, while Diamond diagnosed how inequality shaped civilization’s past, post-anthropogenic design proposes how equitable and networked fabrication ecologies might reshape civilization’s future.

nodes.author: Daggett, C. N.
nodes.title: The Birth of Energy: Fossil Fuels, Thermodynamics, and the Politics of Work
nodes.Description:
Cara New Daggett’s The Birth of Energy: Fossil Fuels, Thermodynamics, and the Politics of Work (2019) interrogates how modern understandings of “energy” emerged alongside industrial capitalism and fossil-fuel dependence. Daggett argues that energy is not merely a physical or scientific concept but a political and cultural construct that has historically disciplined bodies and environments into systems of productivity, efficiency, and control. The thermodynamic framing of energy—as measurable, extractable, and optimizable—helped naturalize the politics of work, embedding capitalist hierarchies into both material systems and social relations. In this sense, the fossil-fuel regime represents not only a technological formation but also a moral and epistemic order, one that organizes life through the relentless conversion of matter into labor and heat.

This analysis directly informs our research, which seeks to move beyond anthropocentric and extractive design paradigms. Daggett’s critique reveals how the dominant industrial logic of energy production mirrors current fabrication systems—centralized, resource-intensive, and oriented toward human productivity rather than ecological balance. By exposing the politics embedded in thermodynamic thinking, Daggett opens the possibility for alternative energetics grounded in care, reciprocity, and interdependence. The dissertation takes up this challenge by proposing decentralized fabrication ecologies that operate through symbiotic exchanges of material and information, rather than extractive conversions of energy and labor.

In this post-anthropogenic framework, fabrication becomes a relational process rather than an industrial output—one that values the vitality of materials and the agency of non-human systems. Whereas Daggett historicizes how energy became a tool of domination, the dissertation envisions how future fabrication can become a tool of collective regeneration. Both works call for a profound rethinking of the material infrastructures that sustain civilization, advocating a shift from fossil-fueled control toward distributed, ethical, and ecologically attuned modes of making.

nodes.author: Chomsky, N.
nodes.title: Year 501: The Conquest Continues
nodes.Description:
In Year 501: The Conquest Continues (1993), Noam Chomsky traces the continuity between early European colonialism and the modern structures of global capitalism, arguing that the mechanisms of conquest—resource extraction, economic dependency, and epistemic domination—persist in contemporary forms of neoliberal governance and technological control. Chomsky reveals how systems of power maintain inequality through the monopolization of resources and knowledge, ensuring that wealth and productive capacity remain concentrated within dominant nations and corporate entities. This ongoing “conquest,” he argues, is sustained not only through military and economic means but also through the ideological normalization of exploitation and hierarchy—where global exchange is framed as free and neutral, while in reality it reproduces structural dependency.

This perspective deeply informs our research, which examines decentralized, symbiotic, and post-anthropogenic design-to-fabrication practices as potential correctives to these enduring asymmetries. Chomsky’s critique of global inequality exposes how the very infrastructures of production—industrial, digital, and ecological—are embedded within colonial logics of control and ownership. In contrast, our research envisions open design ecologies that challenge these hierarchies by redistributing access to material resources, computational intelligence, and design agency. Just as Chomsky calls for the decolonization of knowledge and production, our framework seeks to liberate fabrication from proprietary systems and centralized authority, enabling collaborative exchange, mutual learning, and material reciprocity across scales and species.

Through this lens, fabrication becomes a form of resistance against the continuation of conquest—an effort to reconfigure making as an ethical, collective, and regenerative practice rather than an instrument of domination. By fostering global networks of shared knowledge and distributed production, our work aligns with Chomsky’s vision of dismantling imperial systems through autonomous cooperation and equitable access, transforming design and fabrication into agents of planetary justice rather than tools of exploitation.

nodes.author: Fuller, R. B.
nodes.title: Operating Manual for Spaceship Earth
nodes.Description:
Buckminster Fuller’s Operating Manual for Spaceship Earth (1969) presents a planetary philosophy that reframes humanity’s technological capacities as tools for collective survival rather than instruments of domination. Fuller argues that Earth is a finite, interdependent system—“Spaceship Earth”—whose successful operation requires a shift from short-term, competitive thinking to comprehensive, anticipatory design. Central to this shift is a revaluation of abstraction. Where industrial modernity used abstraction to fragment labor and obscure systemic relationships, Fuller sees abstraction—mathematics, modeling, and global data—as a means to perceive the planet’s ecological and energetic limits with unprecedented clarity.

Fuller critiques the rise of specialization, which he views as a legacy of industrial fragmentation that narrows human understanding. Specialists, focused on isolated tasks, lose sight of the larger systems their work affects. This epistemic narrowing prevents society from recognizing the unintended consequences of industrial growth and resource extraction. To counter this trend, Fuller calls for a new kind of generalist—the “comprehensive designer”—who synthesizes knowledge across disciplines to align human activity with planetary equilibrium.

Automation, for Fuller, is not a threat to human agency but an opportunity to liberate people from narrowly defined labor, allowing them to focus on creativity, invention, and problem-solving. Technology becomes a cognitive prosthesis that enhances our capacity to understand complex systems rather than an opaque force that governs them. Ultimately, Operating Manual for Spaceship Earth advocates for technological intelligibility and planetary stewardship: a global ethic in which humanity learns to navigate complexity, design responsibly at scale, and act as co-custodians of a shared and fragile world.

nodes.author: Fuller, R. B.; Applewhite, E. J.; Loeb, A. L.
nodes.title: Synergetics: Explorations in the Geometry of Thinking
nodes.Description:
In Synergetics: Explorations in the Geometry of Thinking (1975), R. Buckminster Fuller presents a visionary framework that redefines design, structure, and thought as interconnected expressions of universal pattern and systemic coherence. Fuller’s concept of synergetics—the study of systems in transformation—emphasizes how complex wholes arise from the interaction of simple, interdependent parts. Rejecting linear and anthropocentric models of design, Fuller proposes a geometry of thinking rooted in energy flows, dynamic equilibria, and material efficiency. His work anticipates a worldview in which design intelligence is distributed across matter, structure, and environment, suggesting that human invention should harmonize with, rather than dominate, natural processes.

This paradigm profoundly resonates with our research, which explores decentralized and post-anthropogenic design-to-fabrication practices aimed at cultivating global symbiosis and non-standard tectonics. Fuller’s emphasis on pattern integrity and systemic interdependence aligns with the idea that fabrication can operate as an adaptive ecology rather than a linear act of production. Both perspectives view the designer not as a controlling agent but as a participant within a larger network of material and energetic relations.

By translating Fuller’s synergetic principles into contemporary computational and material frameworks, our research extends his geometric philosophy toward transcalar fabrication systems—networks that integrate digital, biological, and environmental intelligence. In this context, design becomes a collective negotiation among multiple agents and scales, embodying Fuller’s belief in comprehensive anticipatory design as a means of planetary stewardship. Where Fuller sought to reveal the underlying geometry of nature as a guide for human invention, our work reinterprets this vision through open, symbiotic fabrication ecologies that enact cooperation between human and non-human systems. Thus, synergetics provides both the geometric and philosophical groundwork for reimagining design as a relational, regenerative, and ecologically attuned practice.

nodes.author: Huxley, A.
nodes.title: Brave New World
nodes.Description:
In Brave New World (1932), Aldous Huxley imagines a meticulously engineered society in which technological mastery, biological manipulation, and social conditioning ensure perfect order at the cost of freedom, emotion, and individuality. Although written nearly a century ago, the novel’s critique of technocratic control and dehumanization feels profoundly contemporary. In an age increasingly defined by automation, algorithmic governance, and data-driven optimization, Huxley’s vision continues to resonate as a prophetic warning: that the pursuit of stability, efficiency, and comfort can easily become a form of enslavement, where humanity surrenders its creative and ethical agency to systems of its own making.

Our research takes this warning seriously, positioning itself explicitly against the dehumanizing trajectories of technological centralization that Huxley anticipated. While Brave New World portrays a future in which design and production are instruments of control, our work explores post-anthropogenic and symbiotic design-to-fabrication practices that seek to restore autonomy, diversity, and mutualism within design ecologies. Rather than consolidating power within closed technological systems, we advocate for decentralized, open, and adaptive modes of fabrication—systems that distribute intelligence, creativity, and responsibility among human and non-human agents alike.

In contrast to Huxley’s standardized, efficiency-obsessed world, our approach promotes plurality and co-creation as essential to the evolution of both technology and culture. It recognizes that design, when stripped of ethical and ecological sensitivity, risks perpetuating the same mechanisms of domination that Brave New World exposed. Thus, our research stands as an act of resistance—an effort to reimagine fabrication not as a means of control, but as a practice of liberation and coexistence. By embracing uncertainty, complexity, and interdependence, we aim to counter the ongoing drift toward technological enslavement and reaffirm design as a fundamentally humanizing and symbiotic endeavor.

nodes.author: Weil, S.
nodes.title: Réflexions sur les causes de la liberté et de l'oppression sociale (Liberty and oppression)
nodes.Description:
Simone Weil’s Oppression and Liberty offers a rigorous analysis of the structural roots of domination in modern societies. Writing in 1934 against the backdrop of industrial capitalism and the failures of orthodox Marxism, Weil argues that oppression does not originate primarily in private property or ideology, but in the organization of labor itself—specifically, in the separation between conception and execution. Industrial production institutionalizes this fracture: those who design, plan, and calculate are separated from those who perform mechanical tasks without understanding their purpose. For Weil, this epistemic asymmetry is the true foundation of alienation. Workers are deprived not only of economic agency but of the ability to comprehend the processes that govern their lives.

Weil critiques both capitalism and Marxism for worshipping production as an end in itself. Whether justified as profit or proletarian output, industrial gigantism subordinates human beings to the imperatives of efficiency, scale, and technical specialization. Machines are not inherently oppressive; they become instruments of domination when access to their methods is restricted. “The profane have access only to results, not to methods,” she writes, diagnosing how bureaucracies, experts, and technocratic elites monopolize understanding.

Freedom, for Weil, is therefore a question of intelligibility. A society is free only when individuals can grasp the logic of the systems they participate in and influence them meaningfully. She calls for a reorganization of production grounded in reciprocity, where knowledge is distributed rather than centralized, and where technological systems are designed to expand comprehension instead of enforcing obedience. Through this framework, Weil reconceives political liberation as the restoration of shared understanding between human beings and the material processes that shape their world.

nodes.author: Lafargue, P.
nodes.title: The Right to Be Lazy [Le droit à la paresse]
nodes.Description:
Paul Lafargue’s The Right to Be Lazy (1883) offers one of the earliest and most radical critiques of industrial capitalism and its moral glorification of work. Writing at the height of mechanization, Lafargue exposes how the cult of labor—promoted by both industrialists and segments of the workers’ movement—served to entrench exploitation rather than abolish it. He argues that machinery, instead of liberating people from toil, had been appropriated by capital to intensify productivity and profit, enslaving humanity to a new regime of mechanical dependence. From his unique perspective, Lafargue identifies a profound contradiction: the very technologies meant to free society from material need have become instruments of discipline, inequality, and alienation, benefiting corporations while impoverishing the collective spirit.

Nearly 150 years later, Lafargue’s warning remains disturbingly relevant. The mechanization of human life continues—only now through digital, algorithmic, and networked forms. Each technological revolution promises liberation, yet repeatedly reproduces new dependencies, new hierarchies, and new forms of control. The cycle of industrialization has not been transcended, only repackaged and accelerated. This historical persistence reveals a deeper structural flaw: a paradigm that equates progress with productivity, and innovation with domination.

Our research directly challenges this enduring logic. By envisioning post-anthropogenic, decentralized, and symbiotic design-to-fabrication systems, we seek to break the cycle of mechanized subjugation that Lafargue identified. Rather than perpetuating technology as an instrument of labor discipline, we propose its reinvention as a medium of liberation, cooperation, and ecological reciprocity. It is time to move beyond a history that endlessly reinvents the same machinery of control. The new paradigm must reject the fetish of productivity and embrace design as a practice of care, interdependence, and collective freedom—realizing, at last, the emancipatory promise that mechanization has long betrayed.

nodes.author: Meadows, D. H.; Meadows, D. L.; Randers, J.; Behrens, W. W.
nodes.title: The Limits to Growth: A Report for the Club of Rome's Project on the Predicament of Mankind
nodes.Description:
Donella Meadows’ The Limits to Growth: A Report for the Club of Rome’s Project on the Predicament of Mankind (1972) marked a turning point in the understanding of humanity’s relationship with planetary systems. Developed at a time when computational modeling was just emerging, the study used early computer simulations (notably through the World3 model) to correlate variables such as population growth, resource depletion, industrial output, and pollution. These simulations produced one of the first quantitative representations of Earth as a complex, interdependent system, revealing that unchecked economic and industrial expansion would inevitably exceed the planet’s ecological capacity. Meadows and her team’s findings were revolutionary precisely because they were enabled by the recent rise of computation, allowing for dynamic modeling of feedback loops and non-linear relationships—concepts that reshaped ecological and systems thinking for decades to come.

Our research aligns with Meadows’ vision of systemic interdependence and ecological limitation, yet it also critiques the technocratic and centralized ethos that often accompanied her project’s institutional reception. While The Limits to Growth was a profound ecological warning, its framing sometimes reinforced the notion that global challenges should be analyzed and managed by elite scientific or policy institutions—a top-down paradigm of control. Our research resists this model, emphasizing bottom-up, decentralized, and participatory forms of design-to-fabrication, where knowledge and agency are distributed across communities, technologies, and ecosystems.

Building on Meadows’ systemic insights and their computational origins, our work reinterprets the relationship between technology and ecology: not as one of management or prediction, but of collaboration and coevolution. We envision a future where computational tools—once used to diagnose planetary limits—are reappropriated to enable open, symbiotic, and post-anthropogenic fabrication ecologies, fostering a shift from global technocracy to collective planetary stewardship.

nodes.author: Thomson, D. W.
nodes.title: On Growth and Form
nodes.Description:
D’Arcy Wentworth Thompson’s On Growth and Form is a foundational text in the study of morphogenesis—the process by which natural forms emerge through physical, mathematical, and environmental interactions. Written in 1917, it is one of the first systematic attempts to explain biological form not through teleology or function, but through underlying structural and energetic laws. Thompson proposed that geometry and material behavior are co-determined by gradients of force, pressure, and growth, positioning form as the result of systemic relationships rather than external design intention.

For our research, the book is crucial because it provides an early theoretical framework for understanding form as a generative process—a notion that directly informs computational and parametric design methodologies. Thompson’s emphasis on transformation, proportionality, and the mapping of one morphology into another anticipates the logic of parametric variation and algorithmic morphogenesis. His work thus offers a proto-parametric worldview, where the designer’s role becomes one of tuning relationships rather than composing fixed forms.

This perspective is particularly relevant to contemporary explorations of post-anthropogenic design-to-fabrication ecologies, where agency is distributed among computational, material, and environmental systems. Thompson’s understanding of growth as an emergent negotiation between matter and context aligns with decentralized and open design practices that favor feedback, adaptation, and systemic interdependence. Moreover, his analysis operates transcalarly—from cellular geometries to animal structures—illustrating how consistent generative principles can link micro-scale material behavior with macro-scale ecological organization.

Ultimately, On Growth and Form serves as both a scientific and philosophical precursor to modern computational design thinking. It repositions form as an evolving process embedded within the dynamics of life and environment, providing an essential conceptual foundation for reimagining design and fabrication as morphogenetic, symbiotic, and ecologically integrated practices.

nodes.author: Haeckel, E.
nodes.title: Art Forms in Nature [Kunstformen der Natur]
nodes.Description:
Ernst Haeckel’s Art Forms in Nature (1899) is a landmark work that visually and conceptually explores the morphogenetic diversity of life through intricate lithographic illustrations of microscopic organisms, plants, and marine species. Combining scientific observation with aesthetic idealization, Haeckel sought to reveal the geometric and symmetrical principles underlying biological form. His depictions of radiolarians, diatoms, and medusae visualize nature as an architectonic system—where beauty emerges from mathematical order and systemic growth patterns.

For my research, Haeckel’s work is significant for its early articulation of natural morphologies as models of generative design. Like D’Arcy Thompson, he recognized that biological form arises from dynamic structural and environmental relationships, offering a prefiguration of computational and parametric understandings of morphology. His focus on pattern, recursion, and proportionality anticipates later developments in algorithmic design and digital fabrication, where geometry becomes an expression of systemic behavior rather than representational imitation.

However, it is necessary to acknowledge that Haeckel’s scientific worldview was entangled with eugenic and teleological ideologies that are philosophically incompatible with the ethical foundations of my research, which rejects hierarchical or deterministic models of life and form. In reinterpreting his work, the value lies not in his sociobiological interpretations but in his analytical visualization of morphogenetic complexity and his recognition of the deep interrelation between natural structures and formal systems.

Viewed critically, Art Forms in Nature provides an aesthetic and conceptual bridge between natural morphology and computational generativity. Its contribution to my research resides in its demonstration that form can be both materially contingent and formally structured—a duality central to post-anthropogenic and symbiotic design paradigms. Haeckel’s visual taxonomy thus remains a valuable resource for understanding form as a manifestation of systemic organization rather than hierarchical control.

nodes.author: Stamets, P.
nodes.title: Mycelium Running: How Mushrooms Can Help Save the World
nodes.Description:
Paul Stamets’ Mycelium Running (2005) explores the vast and intricate networks formed by fungal mycelium, proposing them as a paradigm for ecological intelligence and systemic resilience. Through scientific research and practical case studies, Stamets illustrates how mycelial networks function as the planet’s natural infrastructure—decomposing, regenerating, and connecting diverse ecosystems. He positions fungi not only as vital agents in ecological balance but also as models for understanding interdependence, adaptation, and regenerative cycles within complex systems.

For my research, Stamets’ work is pivotal in articulating a model of symbiotic connectivity that extends beyond metaphor into material and systemic practice. The mycelial network embodies the principles of decentralization, feedback, inter-species collaboration, and non-hierarchical organization that are central to post-anthropogenic design and fabrication approaches. Its distributed intelligence—where each node contributes to the resilience of the whole—provides a biological analogue for open design ecologies and transcalar fabrication systems in which local actions contribute to global coherence.

Moreover, Stamets’ emphasis on mycelium’s capacity for self-organization and environmental adaptation parallels computational and material systems that evolve in response to changing parameters. His ecological vision reinforces the notion that sustainable design emerges from attunement with living processes rather than dominance over them. This aligns closely with the goal of developing design-to-fabrication practices that operate symbiotically within planetary systems.

In essence, Mycelium Running offers both a scientific and philosophical framework for reimagining design as an ecological act—rooted in networks of reciprocity, regeneration, and distributed agency. Stamets’ insights bridge biological and computational thinking, presenting mycelium as a living prototype for sustainable, adaptive, and interconnected modes of design and fabrication.

nodes.author: Allen, S.
nodes.title: From Object to Field
nodes.Description:
In this seminal essay, Stan Allen advances the concept of field conditions as an alternative to object-based, compositional models of architecture. Moving “from individuals to collectives, from objects to fields,” Allen repositions architectural design as a relational and adaptive process governed by local interactions rather than top-down formal control. Drawing analogies from mathematics, physics, and post-minimalist art, he describes field conditions as loosely bounded, non-hierarchical systems in which order emerges through the serial aggregation of parts and the negotiation of contextual forces. His historical and material readings—from the Mosque of Córdoba to Le Corbusier’s Venice Hospital—demonstrate how architecture can embody an algebraic, incremental logic of growth, allowing difference to arise through repetition and local adaptation.

Allen’s framework is especially relevant to our research on post-anthropogenic, decentralized design-to-fabrication practices. His emphasis on bottom-up organization, local agency, and the fluid relationship between construction and form anticipates contemporary notions of distributed intelligence and open-ended design ecologies. The essay’s call for architects to “work with and not against the site” resonates with strategies that integrate environmental feedback, material behavior, and computational fabrication into continuous processes of formation. Moreover, Allen’s later discussion of “flocks, schools, swarms, and crowds” aligns with multi-agent and self-organizing systems central to current algorithmic and ecological design paradigms.

Ultimately, “From Object to Field” provides a foundational theoretical bridge between modernist compositional thinking and emergent, adaptive architectures. It situates architecture within a dynamic field of relations—social, material, and environmental—making it a key precursor to the distributed, transcalar, and symbiotic design frameworks that inform our exploration of post-anthropogenic tectonics.

nodes.author: Allen, S.
nodes.title: ANY 23: Diagram Work: Data Mechanics for a Topological Age
nodes.publisher: ANY / Anyone Corporation van Berkel, B.; Bos, C. (Eds.)
nodes.Description:
In Diagrams Matter, Stan Allen reframes the architectural diagram not as a tool of representation but as an abstract machine—a generative system that organizes relationships between matter, information, and event. Drawing on Deleuze and Guattari’s notion of the diagram as a “constructive” rather than representational device, Allen argues that diagrams operate through transposition rather than translation, converting relationships between heterogeneous media, materials, and scales without the mediation of symbolic meaning. In this sense, the diagram mediates between the actual and the virtual, situating architecture as a performative field where material, technical, and social forces interact dynamically.

Allen’s concept of diagrammatic practice—indifferent to disciplinary boundaries and attentive to feedback between information and matter—directly informs our research into post-anthropogenic, decentralized design-to-fabrication systems. His emphasis on the diagram as an operational rather than representational construct parallels computational and ecological design approaches where agency, emergence, and relational organization supersede fixed typologies or authorial control. The notion that architecture “actualizes the virtual” aligns with distributed fabrication networks and adaptive systems that negotiate between digital information and material behavior in real time.

By positioning the diagram as both medium and method, Allen opens architecture to complex exchanges with its “outside”—technological, social, and environmental systems. This resonates with our research’s focus on open, transcalar, and collaborative ecologies of design. Ultimately, Diagrams Matter provides a theoretical foundation for understanding architecture as a dynamic interface—an evolving network of interactions rather than a static object—anticipating contemporary explorations of algorithmic materialism, decentralized authorship, and symbiotic design processes that redefine tectonics in a post-anthropogenic context.

nodes.author: Snooks, R.
nodes.title: Behavioral Formation: Multi-Agent Algorithmic Design Strategies
nodes.Description:
In Behavioral Formation, Roland Snooks proposes a computational design methodology rooted in agent-based systems, shifting architectural authorship from the direct modeling of form to the orchestration of behavioral environments. Instead of drawing shapes or manipulating parametric surfaces, the designer encodes a set of local rules and interactions that govern the behavior of autonomous agents. Architectural form emerges as the collective, large-scale consequence of these micro-level negotiations.

This approach reframes the designer’s role. Rather than acting as a traditional form-giver or a distant programmer, the designer becomes an ecological orchestrator who constructs the conditions within which emergence occurs. Crucially, Snooks emphasizes that this generative process does not result in black-box opacity: the designer fully understands the rule-based logic, even though the specific outcomes remain unpredictable. Uncertainty is not a limitation but a productive form of nonlinear intelligibility, akin to natural morphogenesis where deterministic processes yield irreducible complexity.

Snooks’ framework represents a philosophical evolution of Deleuzian thought in architecture: the fold is not a stylistic trope but the structural logic of recursive interactions. Form is no longer imposed from above but unfolds from within a field of encoded relations.

Yet the methodology remains bounded by its computational substrate. The emergent behavior is simulated rather than embodied, and material feedback is abstracted rather than directly integrated. As a result, Behavioral Formation outlines a powerful ontology of digital emergence while leaving open the question of how these behavioral ecologies translate into fabrication and material negotiation.

nodes.author: Snooks, R.
nodes.title: Behavioral Formation: Volatile Design Processes and the Emergence of a Strange Specificity
nodes.Description:
This paper articulates a decade-long research trajectory that redefines architectural tectonics through algorithmic design and robotic fabrication. Roland Snooks’ agentBody Prototypes synthesize structure, surface, and ornament into an inseparable whole, collapsing the disciplinary boundaries between expression, performance, and construction. His iterative, experimental methodology couples behavioral multi-agent algorithms with advanced fabrication systems such as wire-arc additive manufacturing and carbon-fiber infusion. Through these methods, tectonics becomes not an outcome but a continuously negotiated process—an evolving material intelligence embedded within both computation and fabrication.

In relation to our research, Snooks’ work offers a vital model for post-anthropogenic design-to-fabrication practices grounded in distributed agency and decentralized formation. His approach dismantles linear, optimization-driven workflows and replaces them with feedback-rich ecologies where design and making co-evolve. This reciprocal relationship between algorithmic intention and material contingency aligns with our exploration of open, transcalar design ecologies capable of fostering global symbiosis between human and non-human agents.

Crucially, Snooks’ position extends—or even resists—the concept of morphospace as a pre-defined domain of possible forms. Rather than operating within a precalculable design space, his work proposes a bounded but dynamic environment in which sets of behavioral rules govern emergent outcomes. Here, both design and fabrication are understood as generative fields—systems that evolve internal logics rather than converging on optimal or predetermined solutions. By embracing this indeterminate, self-organizing framework, Snooks situates tectonic formation as an open-ended, ecological process rather than a finite design problem.

His research thus provides a compelling precedent for our pursuit of decentralized, symbiotic, and post-anthropocentric fabrication cultures—where design intelligence arises from within material, computational, and environmental interplay rather than external control.

nodes.author: Deleuze, G.
nodes.title: The Fold: Leibniz and the Baroque
nodes.Description:
In The Fold: Leibniz and the Baroque, Gilles Deleuze reinterprets Leibniz’s metaphysics to propose a world composed not of discrete substances but of continuous and ever-transforming relations. Leibniz’s concept of the monad—a self-contained, indivisible unit that reflects the entire universe from its unique perspective—suggests a closed, pre-established harmony where each entity mirrors the whole without direct interaction. Deleuze challenges this enclosed model of substance, reimagining the monad not as an isolated atom of being but as a dynamic site of folding and unfolding. The fold becomes a metaphysical and material process through which the inside and outside continually exchange properties, dissolving boundaries between individual entities and their environments.

Architecture has frequently appropriated Deleuze’s concept of the fold to theorize supple, pliant geometry—an understanding that emerged prominently during the digital turn. As critics such as Douglas Spencer note, architectural discourse often drew on Deleuze and Guattari’s process-oriented ideas—like the rhizome, abstract machine, and the smooth and the striated—for their capacity to describe generative, non-hierarchical, and continuous systems. Within this context, the fold was taken up as a spatial and formal principle of continuity and modulation, emphasizing processes of transformation over static representation. However, in Deleuze’s own terms, the fold extends far beyond geometry: it articulates an ontological model of becoming where structure and substance are in perpetual negotiation.

This philosophical shift from fixed substances to differential processes provides a compelling framework for our research into decentralized, post-anthropogenic design-to-fabrication systems. Deleuze’s fold articulates a world of perpetual becoming, where matter, form, and force are co-implicated rather than hierarchically arranged. The fold operates across scales—from the micro-material to the planetary—suggesting an ontology of transcalar continuity that resonates with our aim to integrate digital, material, and ecological systems within open design ecologies. By replacing the monadic enclosure with a logic of interpenetration, Deleuze opens a space for non-linear, emergent modes of production, positioning design and fabrication as co-evolving processes of symbiotic formation.

nodes.author: Cache, B.
nodes.title: Earth Moves: The Furnishing of Territories
nodes.Description:
Bernard Cache’s Earth Moves: The Furnishing of Territories (1995) offers a foundational philosophical and technological framework that resonates strongly with the concerns of our research on post-anthropogenic, decentralized, and open-ended design-to-fabrication practices. Drawing from Deleuze’s concept of the fold, Cache reconceives architecture not as the production of static forms, but as the continuous modulation of forces, surfaces, and territories. The world is not composed of fixed objects but of variable inflections—movements of matter that are always in formation.

At the core of this dynamic ontology lies the notion of the objectile—an object defined not by its final form, but by its generative parameters. The objectile exists as a continuum of potential instantiations, a calculated entity capable of variation across a family of forms. This conceptual shift from mold to modulation prefigures the logic of contemporary file-to-factory workflows, where digital models are directly materialized through computational and robotic systems. For Cache, materialization is not a passive translation of design intent but a co-productive process in which the agency of matter, code, and machine are interwoven.

When framed through the lens of computational design, Cache’s objectile anticipates the principles of morphogenesis and morphospace, where form emerges as a dynamic process within a continuum of virtual possibilities. Just as morphogenetic design explores fields of potential forms governed by parametric and material conditions, the objectile situates architecture within an open, topological landscape of becoming. In relation to our research, this alignment reinforces the move from centralized authorship to distributed, process-oriented ecologies of making. Earth Moves thus provides a critical philosophical grounding for understanding fabrication as a living, adaptive interface—one that enables transcalar, symbiotic design systems in which form, matter, and computation co-evolve beyond anthropocentric paradigms.

nodes.author: Negroponte, N.
nodes.title: Beyond Digital
nodes.Description:
Nicholas Negroponte’s “Beyond Digital” (1998) anticipates a post-digital paradigm in which computation ceases to be a visible technology and instead becomes an invisible substrate of everyday life. His assertion that “the Digital Revolution is over” reframes digitality not as an endpoint but as a condition — an infrastructural atmosphere enabling new modes of existence, production, and organization. For our research, which explores post-anthropogenic design-to-fabrication practices toward global symbiosis, Negroponte’s argument provides an early conceptual grounding for understanding how technological paradigms evolve from instrumental to environmental, from centralized systems of control to distributed ecologies of interaction.

Negroponte’s “five forces of change” — global imperatives, size polarities, redefined time, egalitarian energy, and meaningless territory — prefigure the decentralized, multiscalar frameworks central to our investigation. His vision of a world where “communities formed by ideas will be as strong as those formed by physical proximity” resonates with open design ecologies and networked fabrication systems that dissolve the boundaries between local and global, human and nonhuman, digital and material. The erosion of territoriality and emergence of “unterritorial” collaboration also parallels the ethos of distributed making — where fabrication, resource exchange, and authorship are collectively negotiated across planetary scales.

However, while Negroponte’s vision of a democratic, egalitarian internet seemed plausible in the late 1990s and early 2010s, the trajectory of digital culture has revealed the persistence — and even amplification — of hierarchical structures. The caste system, as he described it, was not merely an artifact of the physical world; it has been replicated and reconfigured in the digital sphere through data monopolies, algorithmic bias, and uneven access to technological agency. His text, though over-optimistic, remains an important speculative provocation — a reminder of what the digital age could and should have become.

Ultimately, Beyond Digital stands as both a visionary and cautionary milestone, articulating the consequences of globalization and the global digitization of life within the interconnected World Wide Web. It frames a horizon our research seeks to reapproach — a post-digital ecology where decentralization, openness, and symbiosis might finally realize the inclusive potential Negroponte once imagined.

nodes.author: DeLanda, M.
nodes.title: Intensive Science and Virtual Philosophy
nodes.Description:
Manuel DeLanda’s Intensive Science and Virtual Philosophy (2002) offers a rigorous philosophical framework for rethinking material processes, morphogenesis, and emergence—ideas that resonate strongly with the theoretical and operative ambitions of our research. DeLanda reinterprets Deleuze’s concepts of the virtual, intensive, and multiplicity through the lens of contemporary science, particularly thermodynamics, nonlinear dynamics, and complexity theory. He proposes that form and structure are not imposed from above but arise through self-organizing processes driven by intensive differences and far-from-equilibrium conditions.

This perspective directly informs our investigation into post-anthropogenic design-to-fabrication practices, where form-finding and material articulation emerge through distributed, adaptive, and non-linear processes rather than fixed human authorship. DeLanda’s insistence on a non-essentialist realism—where material systems possess real capacities and tendencies that actualize through interaction—offers a philosophical grounding for decentralized design ecologies. In this light, fabrication becomes less about control and more about enabling the self-organization of matter across scales and contexts, aligning with the goal of achieving global symbiosis through open and responsive design systems.

DeLanda’s discussion of complexity and emergence also parallels the ethos of computational and transcalar fabrication. His notion that complexity must be understood qualitatively, as the capacity for systems to reorganize through bifurcations and phase transitions, aligns with approaches that treat digital and material processes as generative fields rather than deterministic workflows. Furthermore, his observation that computer simulations “stage interactions between virtual entities from which properties, tendencies, and capacities actually emerge” prefigures the role of computational environments as laboratories for exploring distributed agency and emergent form.

Overall, Intensive Science and Virtual Philosophy provides a conceptual bridge between material ontology and computational design thinking, supporting an understanding of fabrication as a dynamic, emergent negotiation between human, non-human, and material intelligences within a decentralized planetary ecology.

nodes.author: DeLanda, M.
nodes.title: Material Complexity
nodes.publisher: Leach N, Turnbull D, Williams C, eds. Digital Tectonics. Wiley Academy
nodes.Description:
Manuel DeLanda’s essay “Material Complexity” in Digital Tectonics (2004) develops a philosophy of material agency and morphogenesis that powerfully complements the theoretical orientation of our research. Drawing from both materials science and Deleuze’s critique of the hylomorphic model—the idea that form is externally imposed upon inert matter—DeLanda argues for an understanding of design as a process of collaboration with active materials. He illustrates this through the behavior of dislocations in metals, showing how toughness and rigidity emerge as collective, nonlinear phenomena arising from the self-organizing dynamics of defects. For DeLanda, such emergent properties reveal that matter is not passive but endowed with tendencies, capacities, and internal singularities—a thermodynamic vitality that expresses itself most clearly in heterogeneous, far-from-equilibrium conditions.

This view aligns directly with our research’s aim to reimagine post-anthropogenic design-to-fabrication practices as forms of distributed co-production between human and non-human agents. DeLanda’s critique of industrial homogenization—both of materials and of skilled labor—underscores how modern production systems suppressed material variability in favor of efficiency and predictability. By contrast, our work seeks to reclaim heterogeneity and indeterminacy as generative forces within decentralized, open design ecologies. The notion that design can “tease a form out of active material” rather than impose one resonates with emerging computational and robotic fabrication processes that integrate feedback, adaptation, and material responsiveness across scales.

Ultimately, DeLanda’s reflection on material self-organization provides a conceptual bridge between philosophy, materials science, and digital fabrication. It supports an ecological and transcalar understanding of tectonics—one in which structure and form emerge through the negotiation of dynamic, energetic, and affective exchanges between matter, tools, and designers—advancing a vision of symbiotic fabrication practices beyond the anthropocentric paradigm.

nodes.author: Mitchell, W. J.
nodes.title: Constructing Complexity
nodes.publisher: In: Computer-Aided Architectural Design Futures; pp.41–50
nodes.Description:
William J. Mitchell’s Constructing Complexity offers a conceptual framework that resonates strongly with our research’s exploration of post-anthropogenic design-to-fabrication practices. Mitchell defines architectural complexity as the ratio between added design content and added construction content, arguing that the digital revolution has enabled architects to move beyond industrial-era uniformity toward non-repetitive, contextually responsive forms. His account of buildings as “materialized digital information” situates computation not merely as a representational medium but as an active agent in shaping material processes and aesthetic outcomes.

This understanding establishes a productive lens through which to examine our research’s ambition to bridge high-tech and low-tech fabrication ecologies. While Mitchell emphasizes the efficiencies of digitally controlled machinery—laser cutters, multi-axis mills, numerically controlled fabrication—as key enablers of non-standard tectonics, our work situates similar formal ambitions within decentralized, resource-constrained environments where manual labor and distributed making predominate. The resulting friction between digitally scripted design intent and non-automated construction realities recalls Mitchell’s observation that complexity is not simply a matter of geometry but of how information and material processes are coordinated across scales.

By extending Mitchell’s model into post-anthropogenic and transcalar contexts, our research reinterprets “complexity” as a collective and ecological condition rather than a computational one. The ratio between design and construction content becomes a relational metric—mediated by networks of human and non-human actors, open design platforms, and vernacular fabrication practices. In this light, Constructing Complexity provides both a technical foundation and a critical foil: it frames the promise of digital precision and mass customization that our research reimagines through more-than-human, open-ended, and distributed modes of making—toward a globally symbiotic, non-standard architecture.

nodes.author: Waldrop, M. M.
nodes.title: Complexity: The Emerging Science at the Edge of Order and Chaos
nodes.Description:
Waldrop’s Complexity: The Emerging Science at the Edge of Order and Chaos (1992) offers a foundational narrative for understanding systems that evolve, adapt, and self-organize without centralized control—an intellectual framework that deeply informs our research. His account of complexity science, emerging from the Santa Fe Institute, situates adaptive networks, feedback loops, and emergent order as central mechanisms through which diverse agents collectively generate new forms of organization. These principles resonate strongly with post-anthropogenic design-to-fabrication paradigms, which similarly reject linear, deterministic models in favor of distributed, co-evolutionary systems of making.

In complexity theory, Waldrop identifies the “edge of chaos” as a dynamic zone between stability and disorder—where innovation, resilience, and adaptation thrive. This notion parallels our exploration of decentralized open design ecologies, where material, digital, and ecological systems interact continuously, generating non-standard tectonics through emergent feedback rather than prescriptive authorship. The book’s emphasis on self-organization and adaptive processes also aligns with the logic of transcalar fabrication, in which design intelligence is embedded across scales—from the local material agency of fabrication tools to the global networks of open-source collaboration.

By framing design as a complex adaptive system, Waldrop’s narrative encourages a shift from object-oriented to process-oriented thinking. It supports the idea that fabrication practices can act as ecological negotiations rather than isolated technological acts—balancing autonomy and interdependence, order and indeterminacy. In this sense, Complexity provides both a conceptual lens and a philosophical grounding for reimagining design not as a human-centered imposition of form, but as an emergent choreography of relations among human, non-human, and machinic agents. Waldrop’s work thus reinforces the theoretical and systemic ambitions of our research toward global symbiosis through decentralized, adaptive, and ecologically attuned modes of design and fabrication.

nodes.author: Crolla, K.
nodes.title: Building Simplexity: The “More or Less” of Post-Digital Architecture Practice
nodes.Description:
Kristof Crolla’s Building Simplexity (2018) positions architectural design within a post-digital paradigm where computational ambition must be reconciled with the stubborn realities of material construction. For Crolla, complexity is not achieved through increasingly sophisticated algorithms but through a strategic interplay between digital intent and physical constraint. He defines this approach as simplexity: attaining formally rich outcomes through simple, low-tech, and constructible means. Rather than treating fabrication as a downstream act of execution, Crolla insists that it is an active epistemic partner. Architecture emerges through an iterative dialogue among form, matter, material systems, and materialisation, in which material feedback continually reshapes digital decisions.

Crolla’s method remains rooted in parametric design, operating within an expansive morphospace of controlled variations. Here, uncertainty is welcomed but bounded: designers explore possibility through measurable parameters, navigating a continuum of options that remain legible and buildable. Unlike methodologies that foreground digital autonomy or agent-based emergence, Crolla emphasizes reciprocity—the capacity of materials, tolerances, and construction processes to inform and sometimes redirect computational form-finding.

Philosophically, Building Simplexity builds on Deleuze and Cache’s notion of the objectile, but grounds it in the pragmatics of fabrication. Crolla warns that digital experimentation untethered from constructability risks becoming abstract speculation. By restoring material negotiation to the center of design, he reframes post-digital practice as a craft of mediation—one in which computation is not a generator of autonomous complexity but a facilitator of constructive intelligence. Simplexity thus offers a balanced vision for contemporary architecture: where emergence is tempered by embodiment, and where innovation arises from the productive friction between the digital and the real.

nodes.author: Burry, M.
nodes.title: Scripting Cultures: Architectural Design and Programming
nodes.Description:
Mark Burry’s Scripting Cultures: Architectural Design and Programming (2011) articulates a pivotal cultural and technical shift in architecture—from the designer as software user to the designer as digital toolmaker. Central to this transition is what Burry calls authoritative customization: the designer’s capacity to reprogram or script digital tools to align with their own design logic rather than conforming to the limitations of commercial software. This reclaiming of authorship transforms computation from a passive medium into an active collaborator. Such a stance resonates with our research, which explores post-anthropogenic design-to-fabrication practices and decentralized open design ecologies oriented toward global symbiosis.

Burry’s reflections on file-to-factory workflows situate scripting as a critical link between digital design and material realization. He demonstrates how direct digital manufacturing—where code communicates seamlessly with fabrication machinery—enables the production of bespoke, non-standard components without sacrificing efficiency. This paradigm anticipates the distributed fabrication networks that our research seeks to expand, where open protocols and shared digital infrastructures allow for localized, adaptive making across scales and contexts.

Equally significant is Burry’s chapter on “Simplifying Complexity for Fabrication.” Here, scripting is not presented as a means of generating complexity for its own sake, but as a strategy for managing and curating it—translating intricate geometries into constructible, materially responsive systems. This conceptualization aligns with our transcalar fabrication agenda, which frames complexity as an emergent property of collaboration between digital processes, material behavior, and ecological contingencies.

Through the interrelation of authoritative customization, file-to-factory intelligence, and the simplification of complexity, Scripting Cultures offers a foundational framework for rethinking computational authorship and fabrication ethics. It provides valuable theoretical grounding for our pursuit of open, symbiotic, and adaptive design systems capable of bridging digital, material, and ecological domains.

nodes.author: Venturi, R.
nodes.title: Complexity and Contradiction in Architecture
nodes.Description:
In Complexity and Contradiction in Architecture, Robert Venturi challenges the reductive rationalism of modernism, proposing an architecture that embraces ambiguity, tension, and contradiction. His notion of “complexity” celebrates multiplicity and layered meaning — a “both-and” condition that resists the singularity and purity of modernist logic. By reintroducing ornament, symbolism, and historical reference, Venturi destabilized the modernist pursuit of universality and opened a path toward postmodern pluralism. Yet, while positioned as a critique of modernism, Venturi’s postmodernism remains fundamentally top-down and anthropocentric: it privileges the architect’s authorial control and treats complexity as a compositional and aesthetic construct rather than an emergent property of systems. The architect still orchestrates meaning from above, reinforcing human-centered agency and maintaining architecture as a medium of symbolic manipulation rather than ecological or material interaction.

From the perspective of our research, Venturi’s concept of “complexity” can be more accurately understood as complication — the deliberate juxtaposition of contradictory parts within a unified composition. Later theorists such as Greg Lynn and Jeff Kipnis have identified this as “complication masquerading as complexity,” highlighting its dependence on static, representational form rather than on dynamic, self-organizing processes. Venturi’s “complex whole” thus relies on contradiction and collage, not on the adaptive, processual, and distributed logics that define contemporary conceptions of emergence. By contrast, our research reframes complexity as emergent and symbiotic, arising from interactions among materials, agents, and environments. Within decentralized open design ecologies, complexity is not composed but generated — a property of systems in flux, where design intelligence is collectively negotiated across scales and species.

This distinction is critical for defining the boundaries of our research and clarifying that it should not be associated with postmodernism. Venturi’s human-centered, representational complexity provides an essential historical counterpoint — a moment that revealed the limits of composition as a response to modernity. Our work advances beyond this framework toward a post-anthropogenic paradigm, where complexity from emergence, and fabrication simplexity converge to articulate new forms of global symbiosis. In this light, Venturi’s text remains invaluable not as a model, but as a conceptual threshold that delineates where our discourse begins: at the point where complication yields to genuine systemic complexity and where design evolves from authorship to ecology.

nodes.author: Jandrić, P.
nodes.title: Postdigital
nodes.publisher: In: Encyclopedia of Postdigital Science and Education. Springer
nodes.Description:
Jandrić’s (2023) overview of the postdigital provides a critical framework for understanding contemporary technological and cultural production beyond the binary of the digital and analog, aligning closely with the philosophical foundations of our research. The postdigital condition—defined as messy, hybrid, and transdisciplinary—foregrounds an entanglement of technological, biological, and informational systems that resonates with our exploration of post-anthropogenic design-to-fabrication practices. In both cases, the focus shifts from digital novelty to systemic interrelations and socio-material ecologies, where design and fabrication are understood as part of complex, multi-scalar networks rather than isolated technical processes.

Jandrić’s emphasis on rejecting technological instrumentalism and determinism parallels our interest in decentralizing design agency and challenging anthropocentric production paradigms. His account of postdigital scholarship—particularly its commitment to critical pedagogy, social justice, and transdisciplinary knowledge ecologies—supports an expanded notion of design as a political and ethical act embedded in planetary systems. This aligns with our aim to develop open, distributed design ecologies and transcalar fabrication logics that enable forms of global symbiosis between human and non-human agents.

Furthermore, the postdigital’s concern with the “banality” and invisibility of digitality (after Negroponte and Cascone) mirrors our effort to move beyond the fetishization of digital tools toward integrative material practices that engage both computational and environmental intelligences. The postdigital framework thus offers a theoretical lens for understanding how design computation can evolve into relational, hybrid, and context-aware processes—bridging fabrication, ecology, and collective agency. Ultimately, Jandrić’s articulation of the postdigital as a condition of ongoing negotiation and co-emergence provides a conceptual scaffolding for rethinking fabrication as a site of planetary co-design and for situating our research within a broader postdigital and posthumanist discourse.

nodes.author: Cramer, F.
nodes.title: What Is “Post-Digital”?
nodes.Description:
Cramer’s (2014) essay “What Is Post-Digital?” offers a nuanced and materially grounded exploration of how the postdigital emerges from both the saturation and disenchantment with digital culture. Rather than signalling the end of digital technology, Cramer defines the postdigital as a condition in which digital systems have become mundane and are critically recontextualized within hybrid material practices that blend the analog, the digital, and the social. This conception directly informs our research by framing post-anthropogenic design-to-fabrication as a postdigital practice—one that refuses binary distinctions between technological and ecological, synthetic and organic, or high-tech and low-tech production.

Cramer’s analysis of the “DIY versus corporate media” divide and the “maker movement” resonates with our exploration of decentralized open design ecologies. Both challenge the dominance of centralized, proprietary systems by emphasizing distributed, participatory, and materially situated modes of making. His description of postdigital hybridity—where “old” media like printmaking, cassettes, and zines are reactivated within new collaborative frameworks—parallels our interest in transcalar fabrication systems that combine local material intelligence with global digital coordination.

Moreover, Cramer’s critique of “techno-positivist innovation narratives” aligns with our rejection of linear, progress-driven understandings of design technology. Instead, he calls for a pluralistic material culture where tools and processes are valued for their affordances, imperfections, and contextual meanings. This aligns with our vision of fabrication as an ecological negotiation rather than an optimization problem. Finally, his emphasis on the semiotic shift from symbolic code to indexical trace—where making becomes ontological rather than representational—offers a critical lens for rethinking design as a performative act of co-creation within planetary material systems. In this sense, Cramer’s postdigital framework underpins our research’s ambition to situate design-to-fabrication practices within a broader discourse of global symbiosis and relational materiality.

nodes.author: Yan, C.; Yuan, P. F.
nodes.title: Phygital Intelligence
nodes.Description:
Yan and Yuan’s (2024) editorial on Phygital Intelligence situates architectural practice within an emerging paradigm that merges the digital and the physical, redefining how design and construction interface across virtual and material domains. The authors position the “phygital” as a hybrid condition that transcends traditional binaries—between the real and the virtual, the human and the machinic, the local and the global. This conceptual shift resonates directly with the objectives of our research, which explores decentralized and transcalar design-to-fabrication practices aimed at fostering global symbiosis through non-standard, post-anthropogenic tectonics.

Yan and Yuan identify three key areas in which phygital intelligence reconfigures architecture: spatial perception, AI-driven design, and the ecological repositioning of human-nonhuman relations. Their articulation of mixed-reality technologies such as AR/VR and brain–computer interfaces expands spatial cognition beyond static ergonomics, towards adaptive and responsive environments. This aligns with our research’s interest in participatory and distributed modes of making, where human and nonhuman agents co-produce form and performance through data-rich feedback systems.

Furthermore, the authors’ discussion of AI-facilitated generative design underscores a transition from deterministic authorship to collaborative synthesis between designer and machine. Such hybrid intelligence echoes our exploration of open, networked design ecologies—where knowledge and fabrication capacities are decentralized across scales, materials, and contexts. Importantly, Yan and Yuan emphasize that phygital intelligence should not merely yield technological innovation but must engage ethical and ecological reconfigurations of habitation.

By framing architecture as a site of negotiation between virtual intelligence, physical matter, and planetary systems, Phygital Intelligence provides a critical theoretical scaffold for rethinking how post-anthropogenic design practices might operate as instruments of global symbiosis. It substantiates the notion that the future of design-to-fabrication lies not in automation alone, but in the cultivation of hybrid, co-evolutionary intelligences bridging the digital and the ecological.

nodes.author: Baudrillard, J.
nodes.title: The System of Objects
nodes.Description:
Jean Baudrillard’s The System of Objects (1968) offers a prescient critique of automation that directly informs our research. For Baudrillard, technological “intelligence” produces not emancipation but passivity: the more “smart” an object becomes, the less it requires human engagement. Automation transforms users into spectators of their own systems, dissolving the reciprocal, tactile, and interpretive relationship that once bound people to the tools and materials of their world. What appears as technical progress is, for Baudrillard, a subtle erasure of agency—a displacement of creativity into the operational logic of machines.

Our research extends this warning into the contemporary landscape of design-to-fabrication. As computational and automated processes proliferate, the figure of the designer risks becoming another spectator—one who curates rather than constructs, oversees rather than intervenes. Baudrillard’s insight exposes the paradox of “smart” fabrication: intelligence is achieved not through participation but through the elimination of uncertainty and gesture, reducing creativity to the calibration of pre-programmed efficiencies. In this light, automation is not neutral; it carries with it the ideological residue of consumerism, where production, like consumption, becomes an act of observation rather than exchange.

By revisiting Baudrillard’s critique, our research situates post-anthropogenic design within this bleak continuum of technological spectatorship. His argument becomes a cautionary framework: if automation in fabrication merely perfects the system’s self-operation, it risks reproducing the same detachment he diagnosed in consumer society. Rather than opposing his pessimism, our work acknowledges and extends it—examining how post-human design ecologies might confront, rather than conceal, the loss of human agency within the expanding intelligence of machines.

nodes.author: Wiener, N.
nodes.title: Cybernetics: Or Control and Communication in the Animal and the Machine
nodes.Description:
Norbert Wiener’s Cybernetics: Or Control and Communication in the Animal and the Machine (1948) establishes the conceptual foundation for much of contemporary computational design theory and practice. In this seminal work, Wiener articulates a unifying framework for understanding systems—biological, mechanical, and social—through the lenses of communication, feedback, and control. His proposition that both living organisms and machines operate as information-processing systems laid the groundwork for subsequent developments in artificial intelligence, systems theory, and digital computation—fields that deeply inform our research into post-anthropogenic, symbiotic design processes.

Cybernetics introduced the notion of feedback loops as mechanisms of self-regulation and adaptation—principles now fundamental to generative design, parametric modeling, and responsive fabrication systems. Wiener’s recognition of communication as control anticipates the ways computational design operates today: through the continuous exchange of data between designer, system, material, and environment. This relational paradigm supports decentralized and emergent design practices, where form and behavior evolve through interaction rather than top-down determination.

In the context of our research, Wiener’s ideas resonate with the move toward decentralized open design ecologies and transcalar fabrication networks, where intelligence is distributed across agents, materials, and machines. His exploration of the parallels between biological and mechanical systems foreshadows the convergence of computation and ecology in post-anthropogenic design thinking. Cybernetics thus provides not only a technical precedent but also a philosophical one—framing design as a process of negotiation within complex, adaptive systems rather than a purely human act of authorship.

Ultimately, Wiener’s Cybernetics remains foundational to the principles of emergence, feedback-driven form-finding, and systemic interconnectivity that underpin contemporary approaches to computational and symbiotic design. It offers an enduring theoretical lens through which to understand and develop new modes of design-to-fabrication that align with global and ecological entanglement.

nodes.author: Licklider, J. C. R.
nodes.title: Man-Computer Symbiosis
nodes.publisher: IRE Transactions on Human Factors in Electronics, volume HFE-1, pages 4-11
nodes.Description:
In Man–Computer Symbiosis (1960), J.C.R. Licklider proposes a vision of cooperative interaction between humans and computers that extends beyond mere automation. He envisions a partnership in which humans and machines “live together in intimate association” — each complementing the other’s capabilities. Humans, Licklider argues, are best suited to setting goals, formulating hypotheses, and making evaluative judgments, while machines excel at executing routine, data-intensive, or time-sensitive operations. The goal of this symbiosis is not simply efficiency, but a transformation of how thought and decision-making occur, enabling intellectual operations “more effectively than man alone can perform them.”

In relation to our research, Licklider’s framework provides a crucial conceptual grounding for understanding emerging modes of human–machine collaboration in design-to-fabrication systems. His notion of symbiosis anticipates contemporary shifts in computational design, where design authorship and agency are distributed across human and non-human actors. Rather than a hierarchy in which the human designer supervises and the machine executes, symbiotic approaches suggest a co-evolutionary dynamic — one in which tools are not passive instruments but active participants in generative and decision-making processes.

As our research explores decentralized, open, and transcalar fabrication ecologies, Licklider’s ideas invite a re-evaluation of the human’s position within these systems. His early distinction between “mechanically extended man” and truly symbiotic systems parallels the move from conventional automation toward adaptive human–robot teams capable of autonomous reasoning and negotiation. In this light, man–computer symbiosis becomes a theoretical bridge — linking early cybernetic conceptions of cooperative intelligence with post-anthropocentric design practices that aim for global, ecological forms of symbiosis across scales of matter, agency, and computation.

nodes.author: Negroponte, N.
nodes.title: The Architecture Machine: Toward a More Human Environment
nodes.Description:
In The Architecture Machine, Nicholas Negroponte envisions a future in which computers act not as drafting instruments but as intelligent collaborators in the design process. Written during his leadership of MIT’s Architecture Machine Group, the book merges architectural theory with early cybernetics and artificial intelligence, proposing a “two-way conversation” between human and machine. Negroponte argues that design systems should be capable of perception, learning, and adaptation—able to handle ambiguity and evolve through dialogue with the user. The book presents experimental systems such as URBAN5, where the computer interprets spatial input, infers intent, and offers design feedback.

For our research, The Architecture Machine provides an early framework for understanding distributed design intelligence within computational and fabrication contexts. Negroponte’s call for machines that “learn from their users” anticipates the adaptive, data-driven logics that now underpin decentralized and open design ecologies. His notion of a participatory and evolving architecture resonates with our exploration of systems where agency and authorship are shared among human and non-human actors. By emphasizing dialogue and mutual adaptation, Negroponte foreshadows contemporary notions of human–machine symbiosis in design-to-fabrication processes.

The text also introduces a form of transcalar reasoning: the “machine in residence” concept implies computational systems that can negotiate between intimate, human-scale environments and complex, systemic urban or environmental conditions. This perspective parallels our research’s ambition to develop fabrication ecologies operating across scales and disciplines. While Negroponte’s technical reach was limited by the computing capabilities of his time, his theoretical position remains profoundly relevant. His insistence that machines should embrace uncertainty, context, and qualitative reasoning challenges the determinism often associated with automation. Ultimately, The Architecture Machine stands as a foundational vision of post-anthropocentric design practice—one where computational systems evolve toward true symbiosis with human creativity and the built environment.

nodes.author: Mitchell, W. J.
nodes.title: Computer-Aided Architectural Design
nodes.Description:
Mitchell’s Computer-Aided Architectural Design (1977/1979) provides a foundational framework for understanding how computation transforms architectural thinking—from the automation of representation to the structuring of design as a process.
